IV

RULING ON VOTE OF NO-CONFIDENCE AGAINST

DEPUTY MINISTER OF DEFENCE

( ) (The Hon. Speaker) I wish to make this Announcement in furtherance of the Announcement made by me on 19th August, 2025 regarding the Motion titled the No-Confidence Motion, submitted by a group of 32 Members of Parliament of the Opposition, including the Hon. Leader of the Opposition in Parliament on 12th August, 2025 against the Hon. Major General (Rtd.) Aruna Jayasekera, MP and Deputy Minister of Defence.

I have carefully considered this Motion in light of the provisions of the Constitution, the Standing Orders of the Parliament and established Parliamentary practices and precedents.

I also studied the traditions and procedures followed in other Commonwealth and democratic legislatures such as the UK House of Commons, Indias Lok Sabha and Australias House of Representatives in this regard.

Under Articles 42, 43 and 44 of the Constitution of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, collective and individual ministerial responsibility lies with the Cabinet of Ministers. A Deputy Minister, though a Member of Parliament, is not a Member of the Cabinet and does not bear direct Constitutional responsibility to this House in the present context.

189 190

The Constitution clearly recognizes that No-Confidence Motions may be brought against the Government as a whole, while the precedents recognize No-Confidence Motions against the Prime Minister or an individual Cabinet Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in Parliament. But, there is no provision for such a Motion against a Deputy Minister.

Therefore, if such a Motion is to be accepted today, it would establish an undesirable precedent contrary to the Constitutional and Parliamentary precedents.

The Constitution clearly recognizes that No-Confidence Motions may be brought against the Government as a whole, while the precedents recognize No-Confidence Motions against the Prime Minister or an individual Cabinet Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in Parliament. But, there is no provision for such a Motion against a Deputy Minister.

Therefore, if such a Motion is to be accepted today, it would establish an undesirable precedent contrary to the Constitutional and Parliamentary precedents.

Therefore, I am very grateful to the people who have petitioned again to revive the matter. Then, the OMP went there. On the 26th of August, 2025, an expert team including Judicial Medical Officers, forensic anthropologists and archaeologists submitted a request to the Court to go to the mass grave site, as per the Order made. Even now, as we speak, that team is visiting that place; I was told that they were going there and the OMP is handling everything. Based on their findings, they will submit an interim report and then, the Magistrate will give the order for excavation and exhumations.

Then, the budget. Those experts are the ones who give us the budget on everything that is necessary. When that is submitted to the Ministry through proper channels, I will approve the funds. We have enough funds, and this matter will never be sidelined. So, there is enough funds. Even the inquiry into the Chemmani mass graves is proceeding with great speed because of continuous funding. So, funds would be there.

Then, the budget. Those experts are the ones who give us the budget on everything that is necessary. When that is submitted to the Ministry through proper channels, I will approve the funds. We have enough funds, and this matter will never be sidelined. So, there is enough funds. Even the inquiry into the Chemmani mass graves is proceeding with great speed because of continuous funding. So, funds would be there.

(iii) The Court will determine the collaboration of

relevant government institutions, including the Attorney-General, but it would not be limited to him. The Attorney-General would only be one and a main person involved, but subject matter experts would ensure that the excavation process is carried out in full compliance with legal and procedural standards. That multi-disciplinary and inter-agency approach will be adopted to strengthen the credibility, transparency and legal integrity of the entire process, from investigations to potential judicial proceedings. In fact, the Office for Reparations and the Office on Missing Persons have already formulated some proposals to be submitted to our international partners including the UN agencies, seeking their expertise and help. We are not going to leave any stone unturned. If we do not have the expertise, we have to get it

from where it is available, and we are fully open for that. So, whatever technology needed, drones or otherwise, would be provided.

That multi-disciplinary and inter-agency approach will be adopted to strengthen the credibility, transparency and legal integrity of the entire process, from investigations to potential judicial proceedings. In fact, the Office for Reparations and the Office on Missing Persons have already formulated some proposals to be submitted to our international partners including the UN agencies, seeking their expertise and help. We are not going to leave any stone unturned. If we do not have the expertise, we have to get it

from where it is available, and we are fully open for that. So, whatever technology needed, drones or otherwise, would be provided.

The main goal is to reveal the truth, provide answers to their families and communities, honour the memory of the deceased and to uphold human dignity throughout the process.

So, the short Answer to your whole Question is Yes and hoping that the Weather God does not come in the way, by October, this process should be able to be started.

Thank you.

3. It is the policy of the Government to resettle all displaced persons on their original lands. Since assuming office, the Government has released 57.39 acres of land to the rightful owners.
